Geometric and spectral properties of causal maps

Nicolas Curien, Tom Hutchcroft, and Asaf Nachmias
Abstract

We study the random planar map obtained from a critical, finite variance, Galton-Watson plane tree by adding the horizontal connections between successive vertices at each level. This random graph is closely related to the well-known causal dynamical triangulation that was introduced by AmbjÃ¸rn and Loll and has been studied extensively by physicists. We prove that the horizontal distances in the graph are smaller than the vertical distances, but only by a subpolynomial factor: The diameter of the set of vertices at level nğ‘›n is both oâ€‹(n)ğ‘œğ‘›o(n) and n1âˆ’oâ€‹(1)superscriptğ‘›1ğ‘œ1n^{1-o(1)}. This enables us to prove that the spectral dimension of the infinite version of the graph is almost surely equal to 2, and consequently that the random walk is diffusive almost surely. We also initiate an investigation of the case in which the offspring distribution is critical and belongs to the domain of attraction of an Î±ğ›¼\alpha-stable law for Î±âˆˆ(1,2)ğ›¼12\alpha\in(1,2), for which our understanding is much less complete.

1 Introduction

The causal dynamical triangulation (CDT) was introduced by theoretical physicists Jan AmbjÃ¸rn and Renate Loll as a discrete model of Lorentzian quantum gravity in which space and time play different roles [7]. Time is represented by a partition of the d+1ğ‘‘1d+1-dimensional model into a sequence of dğ‘‘d-dimensional layers with increasing distances from the origin. Although this model has been the subject of extensive numerical investigation [5, 6], especially in dimension 2+1212+1 and 3+1313+1, very little is known analytically, let alone rigorously.

In the case of dimension 1+1111+1, the 111-dimensional layers are simply cycles, and causal triangulations are in bijection with plane trees, see e.g. [17, 32]. Figure 2 below illustrates the mechanism used to build a causal triangulation from a plane tree Ï„ğœ\tau: We first add the horizontal connections between successive vertices in each layer to obtain a planar map ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…â€‹(Ï„)ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…ğœ\mathsf{Causal}(\tau) living on the sphere, and then triangulate the non-triangular faces of this map as shown in the drawing to obtain the triangulation ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—‚ğ—€â€‹(Ï„)ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—‚ğ—€ğœ\mathsf{CauTrig}(\tau). See Section 5.1 and [17, Section 2.3] or [32, Section 2.2] for more details.

The maps ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…â€‹(Ï„)ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…ğœ\mathsf{Causal}(\tau) and ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—‚ğ—€â€‹(Ï„)ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—‚ğ—€ğœ\mathsf{CauTrig}(\tau) are qualitatively very similar. We shall focus in this article on the model ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…â€‹(Ï„)ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…ğœ\mathsf{Causal}(\tau) (mainly to simplify our drawings) and refer the reader to Section 5.1 for extensions of our results to other models including causal triangulations.

The geometry of large random plane trees is by now very well understood [2, 9, 15]. However, we shall see that causal maps have geometric and spectral properties that are dramatically different to the plane trees used to construct them. Indeed, the causal maps have much more in common with uniform random planar maps [27] such as the UIPT than they do with random trees.

Setup and results.

Suppose that Ï„ğœ\tau is a finite plane tree. We can associate with it a finite planar map (graph) denoted by ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…â€‹(Ï„)ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…ğœ\mathsf{Causal}(\tau) by adding the â€˜horizontalâ€™ edges linking successive vertices in the cyclical ordering of each level of the tree as in Figure 2. If Ï„ğœ\tau is an infinite, locally finite plane tree, performing the same operation yields an infinite planar map with one end, see Figure 1. The distance between a vertex vğ‘£v of Ï„ğœ\tau and the root ÏğœŒ\rho, called the height of vğ‘£v, is clearly equal in the two graphs Ï„ğœ\tau and ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…â€‹(Ï„)ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…ğœ\mathsf{Causal}(\tau). Thus, a natural first question is to understand how the distances between pairs of vertices at the same height are affected by the addition of the horizontal edges in the causal graph. We formalize this as follows: Let Ï„ğœ\tau be a plane tree with root ÏğœŒ\rho. Theorem 1 (Geometry of generic causal maps).

Let Î¼ğœ‡\mu be critical and have finite non-zero variance. Then

1.1 The Î±ğ›¼\alpha-stable case.

Besides the finite variance case, we also study the case in which the offspring distribution Î¼ğœ‡\mu is critical and is â€œÎ±ğ›¼\alpha-stableâ€ in the sense that it satisfies the asymptotic111Here fâ€‹(k)âˆ¼gâ€‹(k)similar-toğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ‘”ğ‘˜f(k)\sim g(k) means that fâ€‹(k)/gâ€‹(k)â†’1â†’ğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ‘”ğ‘˜1f(k)/g(k)\to 1 as kâ†’+âˆâ†’ğ‘˜k\to+\infty.

In particular the law Î¼ğœ‡\mu is in the strict domain of attraction of the totally asymmetric Î±ğ›¼\alpha-stable distribution (we restrict here to polynomially decaying tails to avoid technical complications involving slowing varying functions). The study of such causal maps is motivated by their connection to uniform random planar triangulations. Indeed, Krikunâ€™s skeleton decomposition [24] identifies an object related to the stable causal map with exponent Î±=32ğ›¼32\alpha=\frac{3}{2} inside the UIPT, see Section 5.2.

We still denote by Tâˆsubscriptğ‘‡T_{\infty} the Î¼ğœ‡\mu-Galtonâ€“Watson tree conditioned to be infinite (the dependence in Î¼ğœ‡\mu, and hence in Î±ğ›¼\alpha, is implicit), and denote by ğ’âˆsubscriptğ’\mathscr{C}_{\infty} the associated causal map. The geometry of Î¼ğœ‡\mu-Galtonâ€“Watson trees with critical â€œÎ±ğ›¼\alpha-stableâ€ offspring distribution is known to be drastically different from the finite variance case. In particular, the size of the nğ‘›nth generation of Tâˆsubscriptğ‘‡T_{\infty} is of order n1Î±âˆ’1superscriptğ‘›1ğ›¼1n^{\frac{1}{\alpha-1}} rather than nğ‘›n, and the the scaling limit is given by the (infinite) stable tree of Duquesne, Le Gall and Le Jan [15], rather than the Brownian tree of Aldous [2].

We prove that there is a further pronounced difference occuring when one investigates the associated causal maps. Namely, while the girth at height rğ‘Ÿr was strictly sublinear in the finite variance case, it is linear in the Î±ğ›¼\alpha-stable case. In particular, we have the following analog of Theorem 1.

Theorem 4 (Geometry of stable causal maps).

If Î¼ğœ‡\mu is critical and satisfies (1) then we have

(i)logâ¡ğ–¦ğ—‚ğ—‹ğ—ğ—râ€‹(ğ’âˆ)logâ¡râ†’râ†’âˆ(a.s.)1Â andÂ (iâ€‹i)limÎµâ†’0infrâ‰¥1â„™â€‹(ğ–¦ğ—‚ğ—‹ğ—ğ—râ€‹(ğ’âˆ)â‰¥Îµâ€‹r)=1.(i)\quad\frac{\log\mathsf{Girth}_{r}(\mathscr{C}_{\infty})}{\log r}\xrightarrow[r\to\infty]{(a.s.)}1\quad\mbox{ and }\quad(ii)\quad\lim_{\varepsilon\to 0}\inf_{r\geq 1}\mathbb{P}\left(\mathsf{Girth}_{r}(\mathscr{C}_{\infty})\geq\varepsilon r\right)=1.

Similar to Theorem 1, the proof of this theorem uses a block-renormalisation argument. We conjecture that in fact râˆ’1â€‹ğ–¦ğ—‚ğ—‹ğ—ğ—râ€‹(ğ’âˆ)superscriptğ‘Ÿ1subscriptğ–¦ğ—‚ğ—‹ğ—ğ—ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ’r^{-1}\mathsf{Girth}_{r}(\mathscr{C}_{\infty}) converges in distribution and more generally that râˆ’1â‹…ğ’âˆâ‹…superscriptğ‘Ÿ1subscriptğ’r^{-1}\cdot\mathscr{C}_{\infty} converges in the local Gromovâ€“Hausdorff sense. These questions will be addressed in a forthcoming work of the first author. This theorem (and its proof) in fact have direct consequences in the theory of uniform random planar triangulations, using Krikunâ€™s skeleton decomposition; see Section 5 for further details.

The adaptation of the techniques used to prove Theorem 2 here yields that the resistance exponent satisfies

ğ”¯â‰¤2âˆ’Î±Î±âˆ’1,ğ”¯2ğ›¼ğ›¼1\mathfrak{r}\leq\frac{2-\alpha}{\alpha-1}, (2)

while the volume growth exponent is known to be ğ”¤=Î±Î±âˆ’1ğ”¤ğ›¼ğ›¼1\mathfrak{g}=\frac{\alpha}{\alpha-1} [11]. Notice that this bound is only useful in the range Î±âˆˆ(3/2,2)ğ›¼322\alpha\in(3/2,2) since we always have ğ”¯â‰¤1ğ”¯1\mathfrak{r}\leq 1. This witnesses that our understanding of the spectral properties of ğ’âˆsubscriptğ’\mathscr{C}_{\infty} in the Î±ğ›¼\alpha-stable case is much less advanced than in the finite variance case. The bound (2) becomes much more interesting in the case of the Î±ğ›¼\alpha-stable causal carpet, which we expect to really have polynomial resistance growth; see Section 5.2 for further discussion. We remark that the spectral properties of the tree Tâˆsubscriptğ‘‡T_{\infty} have been studied by Croydon and Kumagai [11], who prove in particular that Tâˆsubscriptğ‘‡T_{\infty} has spectral dimension 2â€‹Î±/(2â€‹Î±âˆ’1)2ğ›¼2ğ›¼12\alpha/(2\alpha-1) almost surely.

We are embarrassed to leave the following question open:

Open question 1.

Suppose that Î¼ğœ‡\mu is critical and satisfies (1). Is ğ’âˆsubscriptğ’\mathscr{C}_{\infty} a.s.Â transient?

Organization.

The paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 we present the renormalisation technique that enables to bound from below the girth of causal graphs in a â€œquarter-planeâ€ model carrying more independence than ğ’âˆsubscriptğ’\mathscr{C}_{\infty}. This technique is rather general and we hope the presentation will make it easy to adapt to other settings. We also present the subadditive argument (Section 2.3) which gives the sublinear girth in the case of finite variance offspring distribution. Section 3 is then devoted to the careful proof of Theorem 1 and 4, which is done by dragging the quarter-plane estimates through to the original model ğ’âˆsubscriptğ’\mathscr{C}_{\infty}. In Section 4, we use the geometric knowledge gathered thusfar to prove Theorem 3 and deduce Theorem 2. Section 5 is devoted to extensions and comments.

2 Estimates on the quarter-plane model

The goal of this section is to study the girth of random causal graphs. For this, we first define a â€œquarter-planeâ€ model carrying more symmetries and independence properties than Tâˆsubscriptğ‘‡T_{\infty}. We then define the notion of a block and establish the key renormalisation lemma than enables us to lower bound the width of a block (Proposition 1). The outcome of this renormalisation procedure is slightly different depending on whether Î¼ğœ‡\mu has finite variance or is â€œÎ±ğ›¼\alpha-stableâ€. These estimates will later be transferred to the actual model ğ’âˆsubscriptğ’\mathscr{C}_{\infty} in Section 3. In Section 2.3 we present the subadditive argument for the quarter-plane model (Proposition 2) which will enable us to prove that the width is sublinear in the finite variance case.

Before presenting the quarter-plane model, let us start by recalling a few standard estimates on critical Galtonâ€“Watson trees. Recall that Î¼ğœ‡\mu is always a critical offspring distribution and recall the definition of Î²ğ›½\beta above. The famous estimate of Kolmogorov and its extension to the stable case by Slack [33] states that

(3)

Furthermore, conditionally on non-extinction at generation nğ‘›n, the total size of generation nğ‘›n converges after rescaling by nÎ²superscriptğ‘›ğ›½n^{\beta} towards a non-zero random variable (Yaglomâ€™s limit and its extension by Slack [33]):

(nâˆ’Î²#âˆ‚[T]nâˆˆâ‹…âˆ£ğ–§ğ–¾ğ—‚ğ—€ğ—ğ—(T)â‰¥n)â†’nâ†’âˆ(d)ğ’³,\displaystyle\left(n^{-\beta}\#\partial[T]_{n}\in\cdot\mid\mathsf{Height}(T)\geq n\right)\xrightarrow[n\to\infty]{(d)}\mathcal{X}, (4)

where ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} is an explicit positive random variable (but whose exact distribution will not be used in the sequel).

2.1 The block-renormalisation scheme

The quarter-plane model.

We consider a sequence T1,T2,â€¦subscriptğ‘‡1subscriptğ‘‡2â€¦T_{1},T_{2},\dots of independent and identically distributed Î¼ğœ‡\mu-Galtonâ€“Watson trees. We can then index the vertices of this forest by {1,2,â€¦}Ã—{0,1,â€¦}12â€¦01â€¦\{1,2,\ldots\}\times\{0,1,\ldots\} in an obvious way as depicted in the Figure 3 below.

Adding the horizontals edges (i,j)â†”(i+1,j)â†”ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘–1ğ‘—(i,j)\leftrightarrow(i+1,j) forms an infinite planar map (graph) which we call the quarter-plane model and denote by ğ’¬âˆsubscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}_{\infty}. Let Î¾râ‰¥1subscriptğœ‰ğ‘Ÿ1\xi_{r}\geq 1 be minimal such that TÎ¾rsubscriptğ‘‡subscriptğœ‰ğ‘ŸT_{\xi_{r}} reaches height rğ‘Ÿr. The block of height rğ‘Ÿr, denoted ğ’¢rsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{G}_{r}, is defined to be the subgraph of ğ’¬âˆsubscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}_{\infty} induced by the vertices of T1,â€¦,TÎ¾rsubscriptğ‘‡1â€¦subscriptğ‘‡subscriptğœ‰ğ‘ŸT_{1},\dots,T_{\xi_{r}} at height less than or equal to rğ‘Ÿr. That is, ğ’¢rsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{G}_{r} consists of all the vertices of T1,â€¦,TÎ¾rsubscriptğ‘‡1â€¦subscriptğ‘‡subscriptğœ‰ğ‘ŸT_{1},\dots,T_{\xi_{r}} at height less than or equal to rğ‘Ÿr and all the edges of ğ’¬âˆsubscriptğ’¬\mathcal{Q}_{\infty} (both horizontal and vertical) between them. See Fig.Â 3 for an illustration. Clearly, we can speak of the two sets of vertices belonging respectively to the left side and right side of the block ğ’¢rsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{G}_{r}, that is, the set of r+1ğ‘Ÿ1r+1 left most vertices and the set of r+1ğ‘Ÿ1r+1 right most vertices of the block. We define the width of ğ’¢rsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{G}_{r}, denoted by ğ–¶ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—â€‹(ğ’¢r)ğ–¶ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—subscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ\mathsf{Width}(\mathcal{G}_{r}), to be the minimal graph distance (in ğ’¢rsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{G}_{r}) between a vertex in the left side and a vertex in the right side of ğ’¢rsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{G}_{r}, see Fig.Â 3. The width of a block is not uniformly large when rğ‘Ÿr is large: Indeed, the first tree T1subscriptğ‘‡1T_{1} may actually reach the level rğ‘Ÿr in which case ğ–¶ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—â€‹(ğ’¢r)=0ğ–¶ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—subscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ0\mathsf{Width}(\mathcal{G}_{r})=0. However, we will see that a large block typically has a large width. To this end, we consider the median of ğ–¶ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—â€‹(ğ’¢r)ğ–¶ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—subscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ\mathsf{Width}(\mathcal{G}_{r}):

Definition 1.

For each râ‰¥1ğ‘Ÿ1r\geq 1 let fâ€‹(r)ğ‘“ğ‘Ÿf(r) be the median width of ğ’¢rsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{G}_{r}, that is, the largest number such that

â„™â€‹(ğ–¶ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—â€‹(ğ’¢r)â‰¥fâ€‹(r))â‰¥1/2.â„™ğ–¶ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—subscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿğ‘“ğ‘Ÿ12\mathbb{P}\big{(}\mathsf{Width}(\mathcal{G}_{r})\geq f(r)\big{)}\geq 1/2.

As usual, the dependence on the offspring distribution is implicit in the notation. Obviously the value 1/2121/2 is not special. Note that, depending on Î¼ğœ‡\mu, one might have that fâ€‹(r)=0ğ‘“ğ‘Ÿ0f(r)=0 for small values of rğ‘Ÿr. On the other hand, ğ–¶ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—â€‹(ğ’¢ğ“‡)ğ–¶ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—subscriptğ’¢ğ“‡\mathsf{Width}(\mathcal{G_{r}}) is bounded deterministically by 2â€‹r2ğ‘Ÿ2r since all vertices in the top layer of ğ’¢rsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{G}_{r} share a common ancestor in level zero, so that fâ€‹(r)â‰¤2â€‹rğ‘“ğ‘Ÿ2ğ‘Ÿf(r)\leq 2r also. Our main technical result shows that fâ€‹(r)ğ‘“ğ‘Ÿf(r) is always roughly linear, more precisely:

Theorem 5 (fâ€‹(r)ğ‘“ğ‘Ÿf(r) is almost linear).

If Î¼ğœ‡\mu is critical and satisfies (1) then there exists c>0ğ‘0c>0 such that

fâ€‹(r)â‰¥câ€‹rğ‘“ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘Ÿf(r)\geq c\,r (5)

for all rğ‘Ÿr sufficiently large. On the other hand, if Î¼ğœ‡\mu is critical and has finite non-zero variance then there exists C>0ğ¶0C>0 such that

fâ€‹(r)â‰¥râ€‹expâ¡(âˆ’Câ€‹logâ¡r)ğ‘“ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ¶ğ‘Ÿf(r)\geq r\exp(-C\sqrt{\log r}) (6)

for all rğ‘Ÿr sufficiently large.

The above theorem is an analytic consequence of the following proposition which encapsulates the renormalisation scheme. Recall the definition of Î²â‰¥1ğ›½1\beta\geq 1 at the end of the Introduction.

Proposition 1.

There exists c>0ğ‘0c>0 such that for any 1â‰¤mâ‰¤câ‹…r1ğ‘šâ‹…ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ1\leq m\leq c\cdot r we have

We also recall the following classical Chernoff-type bound for sums of indicator random variables [4, Corollary A.1.14], which will be used throughout the paper: For every Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0 there exists a constant cÎµ>0subscriptğ‘ğœ€0c_{\varepsilon}>0 such that for every kâ‰¥1ğ‘˜1k\geq 1 and every sequence X1,â€¦â€‹Xksubscriptğ‘‹1â€¦subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜X_{1},\ldots X_{k} of mutually independent {0,1}01\{0,1\}-valued random variables, the sum Y=âˆ‘i=1kXiğ‘Œsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–Y=\sum_{i=1}^{k}X_{i} satisfies the bound

â„™â€‹(|Yâˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[Y]|â‰¥Îµâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹[Y])â‰¤2â€‹eâˆ’cÎµâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹[Y].â„™ğ‘Œğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘Œğœ€ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘Œ2superscriptğ‘’subscriptğ‘ğœ€ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘Œ\mathbb{P}\Bigl{(}\bigl{|}Y-\mathbb{E}[Y]\bigr{|}\geq\varepsilon\,\mathbb{E}[Y]\Bigr{)}\leq 2e^{-c_{\varepsilon}\mathbb{E}[Y]}. (8)

We are now ready to proceed with the proof of Proposition 1.

2.2 The dual width

In order to analyze resistances, it is more convenient to have control of the width of the dual of a block than of the block itself. Given râ‰¥1ğ‘Ÿ1r\geq 1 and a block ğ’¢rsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{G}_{r}, we define the dual width of ğ’¢rsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{G}_{r}, denoted ğ–¶ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—â€ â€‹(ğ’¢r)superscriptğ–¶ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—â€ subscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ\mathsf{Width}^{\dagger}(\mathcal{G}_{r}), to be length of the shortest path in the planar dual of ğ’¢rsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{G}_{r} that starts and ends in the outside face, has its first and last edges in the left and right-hand boundaries of ğ’¢rsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{G}_{r} respectively, and which does not visit the outside face other than at its endpoints. We call such a path a dual left-right crossing of ğ’¢rsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{G}_{r}.

We claim that the dual width of ğ’¢rsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{G}_{r} is equal to the maximal size of a set of edge-disjoint (primal) paths from the bottom to the top of ğ’¢rsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{G}_{r} (we call such a path a primal bottom-top crossing), whence its close connection to resistances. One such maximal set of primal bottom-top crossings can be found algorithmically by first taking the left-most primal bottom-top crossing, then the left-most primal bottom-top crossing that is edge-disjoint from the first one, and so on. The claim can be proved using the cut-cycle duality [19, Theorem 14.3.1] and Mengerâ€™s theorem, but can also easily be checked in our situation, see FigureÂ 6 below.

For each râ‰¥1ğ‘Ÿ1r\geq 1, we define gâ€‹(r)ğ‘”ğ‘Ÿg(r) to be the median dual width of ğ’¢rsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{G}_{r}, that is, the largest number such that

â„™â€‹(ğ–¶ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—â€ â€‹(ğ’¢r)â‰¥gâ€‹(r))â‰¥1/2.â„™superscriptğ–¶ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—â€ subscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿğ‘”ğ‘Ÿ12\mathbb{P}\big{(}\mathsf{Width}^{\dagger}(\mathcal{G}_{r})\geq g(r)\big{)}\geq 1/2.

The proof of Theorem 1 goes through essentially unchanged to yield that there exists a constant c>0ğ‘0c>0 such that

gâ€‹(r)â‰¥câ‹…minâ¡{m;(r/m)Î²â€‹gâ€‹(m)}âˆ€1â‰¤mâ‰¤câ‹…r,formulae-sequenceğ‘”ğ‘Ÿâ‹…ğ‘ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ›½ğ‘”ğ‘šfor-all1ğ‘šâ‹…ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ\displaystyle g(r)\geq c\cdot\min\Big{\{}m;(r/m)^{\beta}g(m)\Big{\}}\qquad\forall 1\leq m\leq c\cdot r,

from which we obtain as before the following analogue of Theorem 5.

Theorem 6 (gâ€‹(r)ğ‘”ğ‘Ÿg(r) is almost linear).

If Î¼ğœ‡\mu is critical and satisfies (1) then there exists c>0ğ‘0c>0 such that for all rğ‘Ÿr large enough we have

gâ€‹(r)â‰¥câ€‹r.ğ‘”ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘Ÿg(r)\geq c\,r.

On the other hand, if Î¼ğœ‡\mu is critical and has finite non-zero variance then there exists C>0ğ¶0C>0 such that for all rğ‘Ÿr large enough we have

gâ€‹(r)â‰¥râ€‹expâ¡(âˆ’Câ€‹logâ¡r).ğ‘”ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ¶ğ‘Ÿg(r)\geq r\exp(-C\sqrt{\log r}).

4 Resistance growth and spectral dimension

In this section we will prove Theorem 2, via Theorem 3. Since certain arguments are valid in general, we highlight when finite variance is needed.

4.1 Resistance

The resistance will be controlled through the method of random paths and builds upon the geometric estimates established in the preceding section. In this section, all resistances will be taken with respect to the graph ğ’âˆsubscriptğ’\mathscr{C}_{\infty}. Before diving into the proof of Theorem 3, we first prove that ğ’âˆsubscriptğ’\mathscr{C}_{\infty} is recurrent (i.e., that ğ–±ğ–¾ğ–¿ğ–¿(Ïâ†”Brc)=ğ–±ğ–¾ğ–¿ğ–¿(Ïâ†”âˆ‚[Tâˆ]r+1;ğ’âˆ)â†’âˆ\mathsf{R_{eff}}(\rho\leftrightarrow B_{r}^{c})=\mathsf{R_{eff}}(\rho\leftrightarrow\partial[T_{\infty}]_{r+1};\mathscr{C}_{\infty})\to\infty as râ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘Ÿr\to\infty).

Proposition 4.

If Î¼ğœ‡\mu has finite non-zero variance then ğ’âˆsubscriptğ’\mathscr{C}_{\infty} is recurrent almost surely.

Proof.

We apply the Nashâ€“Williams criterion for recurrence [30, (2.14)], using the obvious collection of cut-sets given by the sets of edges linking level rğ‘Ÿr to level r+1ğ‘Ÿ1r+1 for each râ‰¥1ğ‘Ÿ1r\geq 1. This edge set has cardinality precisely #â€‹âˆ‚[Tâˆ]r+1#subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿ1\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{r+1} so the proposition reduces to checking that

âˆ‘r=1âˆ1#â€‹âˆ‚[Tâˆ]r=âˆ,Â almost surely.superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ11#subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ŸÂ almost surely\sum_{r=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{r}}=\infty,\quad\mbox{ almost surely}.

Since we have that 1#â€‹âˆ‚[Tâˆ]r=1râ€‹r#â€‹âˆ‚[Tâˆ]r1#subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿ#subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿ\frac{1}{\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{r}}=\frac{1}{r}\frac{r}{\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{r}} and by (18) that the random variable r#â€‹âˆ‚[Tâˆ]rğ‘Ÿ#subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿ\frac{r}{\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{r}} converges in law towards a positive random variable, the last display is a direct consequence of Jeulinâ€™s Lemma [22, Proposition 4 c]. âˆ

Remark.

Let us briefly discuss quantitative resistance lower bounds. It follows immediately from Nash-Williams that

ğ”¼[ğ–±ğ–¾ğ–¿ğ–¿(Ïâ†”Brc)]â‰¥âˆ‘k=1r1kğ”¼[k#â€‹âˆ‚[Tâˆ]k]â‰¥clogr\mathbb{E}\left[\mathsf{R_{eff}}(\rho\leftrightarrow B_{r}^{c})\right]\geq\sum_{k=1}^{r}\frac{1}{k}\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{k}{\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{k}}\right]\geq c\log r

for some c>0ğ‘0c>0 by (18). With a little further effort one can prove an almost sure lower bound on the resistance growth of the form

ğ–±ğ–¾ğ–¿ğ–¿(Ïâ†”Brc)â‰¥âˆ‘k=1r1#â€‹âˆ‚[Tâˆ]kâ‰¥clogrÂ for allÂ nÂ sufficiently large a.s.\mathsf{R_{eff}}(\rho\leftrightarrow B_{r}^{c})\geq\sum_{k=1}^{r}\frac{1}{\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{k}}\geq c\log r\qquad\text{ for all $n$ sufficiently large a.s.}

Indeed, in the analogous statement for the CSBP the contributions from successive dyadic scales form a stationary ergodic sequence and the result follows from the ergodic theorem. Pushing this argument through to the discrete case requires one to handle some straightforward but tedious technical details. We do not pursue this further here.

4.2 Spectral dimension and diffusivity (Theorem 2)

We can now prove Theorem 2.

5 Extensions and comments

5.1 Back to Causal Triangulations

Definition 2.

A causal triangulation is a finite rooted triangulation of the sphere such that the maximal distance to the origin of the map is attained by a single vertex, and for each kâ‰¥0ğ‘˜0k\geq 0 the subgraph induced by the set of vertices at distance kâ‰¥0ğ‘˜0k\geq 0 from the origin is a cycle.

In this work, we focused on the model ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…â€‹(Ï„)ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…ğœ\mathsf{Causal}(\tau) which is obtained from a plane tree Ï„ğœ\tau by adding the horizontal connections between vertices are the same generation. As explained in Figure 2, to get a causal triangulation one needs also to triangulate the faces from their top right corners. (Furthermore, one must add a point at the top of the graph to triangulate the top most face, even if this face is already a triangle). As explained in [17] this construction is a bijection between the set of finite rooted plane trees and the set of finite causal triangulations.

When this procedure is applied to the uniform infinite random tree ğ•‹âˆsubscriptğ•‹\mathbb{T}_{\infty} (which is distributed as a critical geometric Galton-Watson tree conditioned to survive forever) the resulting map ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—‚â€‹(ğ•‹âˆ)ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—‚subscriptğ•‹\mathsf{CauTri}(\mathbb{T}_{\infty}) is the uniform infinite causal triangulation (UICT) as considered in [17, 32]. The large scale geometries of ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—‚â€‹(Tâˆ)ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—‚subscriptğ‘‡\mathsf{CauTri}({T}_{\infty}) and ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…â€‹(Tâˆ)ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…subscriptğ‘‡\mathsf{Causal}({T}_{\infty}) are very similar and it is easy to adapt the results of the present paper to this setting.

Moreover, while it is certainly possible to simply run our arguments again to analyze ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—‚ğ—€â€‹(Tâˆ)ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—‚ğ—€subscriptğ‘‡\mathsf{CauTrig}(T_{\infty}) instead of ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…â€‹(Tâˆ)ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…subscriptğ‘‡\mathsf{Causal}(T_{\infty}), it is also possible to simply deduce versions of each of our main theorems concerning ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—‚â€‹(Tâˆ)ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—‚subscriptğ‘‡\mathsf{CauTri}(T_{\infty}) from the statements that we give. Indeed, using the fact that the largest face in the first nğ‘›n levels of ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…â€‹(Tâˆ)ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…subscriptğ‘‡\mathsf{Causal}(T_{\infty}) is at most logarithmically large in nğ‘›n yields that distances within the first nğ‘›n levels of ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—‚ğ—€â€‹(Tâˆ)ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—‚ğ—€subscriptğ‘‡\mathsf{CauTrig}(T_{\infty}) are smaller than those in ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…â€‹(Tâˆ)ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…subscriptğ‘‡\mathsf{Causal}(T_{\infty}) by at most a logarithmic factor. Moreover, an analogue of the resistance upper bound of Theorem 3 follows immediately since ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…â€‹(Tâˆ)ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ—Œğ–ºğ—…subscriptğ‘‡\mathsf{Causal}(T_{\infty}) is a subgraph of ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—‚â€‹(Tâˆ)ğ–¢ğ–ºğ—ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—‚subscriptğ‘‡\mathsf{CauTri}(T_{\infty}).

We let the reader stare at the two beautiful pictures in Figure 10.

5.2 Causal carpets

Finally, we want to stress that our results can be adapted to various other graphs obtained from trees by â€œadding the horizontal connectionsâ€. For example one could decide, when transforming a plane tree Ï„ğœ\tau to add the horizontal connections but only keeping the extreme most edges of each branch point, see Figure 11.

We call this graph the causal carpet associated to the tree. The geometry of the Î±ğ›¼\alpha-stable causal carpet is very different from the maps studied in this work, since the faces of this map may now have very large degree. In spite of this, the block-renormalisation methodology developed in Section 2 carries through to this model, and analogs of Theorem 4, as well as of the resistance exponent bound

ğ”¯â‰¤2âˆ’Î±Î±âˆ’1ğ”¯2ğ›¼ğ›¼1\mathfrak{r}\leq\frac{2-\alpha}{\alpha-1}

hold true. Alas, this resistance bound becomes trivial precisely at the most interesting value of Î±=3/2ğ›¼32\alpha=3/2, for which a graph closely related to the causal carpet can be realized as a subgraph of the UIPT via Krikunâ€™s skeleton decomposition or via the recent construction of [12]. Indeed, it remains open to prove any sublinear resistance upper bound for the UIPT. Such a bound would (morally) follow from the Î±=3/2ğ›¼32\alpha=3/2 case of the following conjecture.

Conjecture 1.

Let Î¼ğœ‡\mu be critical and satisfy (1) for some Î±âˆˆ(1,2)ğ›¼12\alpha\in(1,2). Then the resistance growth exponent ğ”¯ğ”¯\mathfrak{r} of the associated causal carpet exists and satisfies 0<ğ”¯<10ğ”¯10<\mathfrak{r}<1 almost surely. In particular, the causal carpet is recurrent almost surely.

Despite the sub-optimality of our spectral results in this context, the geometric results obtained by our methods are sharp. The applications of our methodology to uniform random planar triangulations will be explored further in a future work.

Finally, we remark that a model essentially equivalent to the uniform CDT arises as a certain Î³â†“0â†“ğ›¾0\gamma\downarrow 0 limit of Liouville Quantum Gravity (LQG) in the mating-of-trees framework [14, 20]. (More specifically, it arises as the Î³â†“0â†“ğ›¾0\gamma\downarrow 0 limit of the mated-Galton-Watson-tree model of LQG, in which the correlation of the encoding random walks tends to âˆ’11-1). Thus, further study of the uniform CDT may prove useful for understanding LQG in the small Î³ğ›¾\gamma regime, which has recently been of great interest following Ding and Goswamiâ€™s refutation of the Watabiki formula [13].

Added in proof. Gwynne and Miller [21] recently proved sub-polynomial resistance estimates for the UIPT. Conjecture 1 and the analogous question for the skeleton of the UIPT remain open, however.
